text:
Good charcoal roasted bock. Not bad but not amazing. ---Rated via BeerBuddy for iPhone.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 oz bottle served fairly cold. 

A lightly sweet Dunkle Bock that leans strongly towards a Schwarzbier but with exceptional notes of chocolate and coffee. There are also some nice roasted nut notes in the aroma. While the flavor leans towards a 7, the aroma is s solid 8. 

O recommended.

ABC Orlando bottle with a January 2014 enjoy by date....ooops. Dark brown color with a small tan head. Aroma is light chocolate and molasses with some lurking coffee. Flavor has a nice espresso-like bitterness. Nice.
"Light cocoa and coffee on the nose and especially in the flavor. Malt heavy and just a touch sweet. Pleasant and easy to drink. Could be one that I increase tr score down the road."

Pours dark cola into a shaker. Mocha head with medium retention recedes to skim surface. Dark chocolate, pit fruit and espresso aromas. Sweet chocolate and milk upfront turning to dry espresso in the lasting finish.
Cocoa, caramels, light notes of dark fruits, medium sweet, slick medium body, tasty, easy to drink.
Pours black, with a dark tan head. Light aroma of malts and dark fruits. Taste of malts and coffee, with a hint of licorice. Nice palate. A very good black lager. Thumbs up.

Dark brown to black color. Aroma is def chocolate. No coffee or chocolate in this brew...whoa they are right, that is cool. Tastes like a malty chocolate coffee porter. I would never guess this is a lager. Alc is present in the afterbreath. Medium to full bodied with big cocoa and coffee...so weird, yet so good.

1/25/14. 12oz bottle from Trader Joes in Tallahassee. Amber pour with a small khaki head. Caramel and metal on the aroma, otherwise bland. Mild toasty flavor, caramel, hints of chocolate, more metal. Meh.

Bottle poured a clear reddish brown with a lingering ring of tan foam. Aromas of cocoa, caramel, toasted malt and light coffee. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of cocoa, caramel, light coffee and a hint of earthiness with a smooth lingering cocoa finish.

Bottled 15JAN14

Pours brown with a broken sheet of tan foam. Smells roasty and meaty with plenty of toasted malts. Flavor is milky, chocolate, some rye, some sweet dough and a little coffee. Medium to light body with a dry finish. Good beer.

From the 12 fl. oz. bottle. They declare on the label that this is not brew with coffee or chocolate but your senses will say otherwise. Aint that the truth? The pour is dark brown with a modest tan head that becomes a ring and laces. But the nose is alive with coffee and milk chocolate malts and a hint of butter or butterscotch. The body is light to medium. The taste is more sweet than anything else at first but the bitterness tends to evolve with each passing sip.

Deep dark brown coloured body with a muddied glow of amber and a three centimetre tall tan head. Aroma of rich pit fruit sugars coupled with a strong malty character. Medium-bodied; Earthy showing of malt up front with a lot of caramel, toffee and pit fruit sweetness right behind and a touch of chocolate noticeable as well. Aftertaste shows the malt throughout with a good full-bodied flavour and a smooth sweetness at the end. Overall, a very nice dunkles and a good example of the style - strong and earthy with a deep richness and complexity. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Arrowine in Arlington, Virginia for US$2.99 sampled after a hockey game in November 2013 - Thanks Kev!

Pours deep deep read with a light brown head that fades to a thick 1/4" ring around the rim of the glass. Roasty chocolatey, rich bready malts, toffee, caramels, dark fruits. Flavor is roast, dark chocolates, dark fruits, raisins, cherries, floral hops, sweet malts. Pretty tasty.

12oz bottle from trader joes, room temperature. Pours black. Jet black. Blacker than Tobys you-know-what. Some beige head that disappears quickly and completely. Smells like chocolate and cola and figs and... acetone? The bottle says coffee too but I dont detect any. First sip: figs, cola, roast. No coffee or chocolate. Bubbles dance on the tongue for a few seconds and then the mocha kicks in and lingers. A bit sticky on the lips afterwards. Very drinkable.

12oz bottle in Seattle. Quite dark, clean still pour. Soft sweet, chocolate-smoke malt aroma. Porter like malts but a nice fresh, full dark lager body. Not the bock that I think of but this is a really tasty beer. Lots of depth, sweet fruit but smoky dark malt too. Nice.

Tallahassee, Fl - Trader Joes - 12 oz bottle - deep dark brown pour, sticky mocha colored head with a nice coat of lacing. Aroma has some nice date and molasses notes. Full-bodied flavor with nice chocolate notes, hints of dates and molasses, some sweet caramel notes in the finish. Thick sticky mouthfeel. Most definitely worth the $1.17 I paid for it - may need to go back and actually buy a six of this!
Special blend of stuff to bring forth chocolate and coffee notes. Finishes well. Dark chocolate in color. Not too sweet.

Pours dark mahogany. Aroma of dark fruit, a little chocolate. Taste is wintery but without spice, slight coffee notes, dark dry fruits, fig. The palate is medium but towards the full side, a little creamy. Overall a nice winter brew. Smooth and enjoyable. Worth checking out.

Flavorful lager with notes of coffee and chocolate. Your mouth wont insist theres any actual coffee or chocolate in it, as the label claims it will (You can tell there isnt), but there are definitely what wed refer to in beer terms as chocolate and coffee notes that would be hard to miss. I prefer when brewers create tastes with basic beer ingredients instead of adding adjuncts anyhow (Yes, coffee and chocolate count as adjuncts). Good beer that achieves seasonal taste with malts and brewing technique versus tossing sugar, spices, coco, etc. into the brewing vat.

Full Sail LTD 06 has a thick, cream-colored head, a dark, red-brown, clear (not hazy), bubbly appearance, with significant lacing left behind. The aroma is of deep and dark-roasted barley malt, sugar, and brown bread crust. Taste is of dark-roasted barley malt, sweetness, and a bit of bitterness at the end. I do not taste coffee or chocolate, and I do not detect any alcohol with this one. Mouthfeel is medium, and Full Sail LTD 06 finishes mostly wet, refreshing, easy drinking, smooth, and very delicious. RJT

Pours dark chestnut brown with a medium tan creamy head. Aroma is sweet caramel malt, notes of plum, roasty malt, mild cacao and espresso like bitterness. Taste the same as aroma. Palate is a medium body, rich and creamy with good carbonation and slightly sticky mouth feel. The finish is sweet sticky caramel malt, dark fruit, a nice chocolate and roasted espresso bitterness in the end for balance. A very rich and full flavored brew. Overall a good flavorful and tasty brew for the holidays.

12oz bottle. Medium tan head atop clear dark brown body. Aroma is moderately sweet, caramel, some milk chocolate, coffee. Taste is moderately sweet, milk chocolate, some plum, caramel, light coffee.  Slightly cloying. Soft medium body, some stickiness.

Location/Date:Bottle on December 13th, 2013.
Appearance: Pours a dark brown black with light white head. 
Aroma: Aroma of coffee, chocolate, faint roast, light caramel.
Taste: Caramel, light chocolate.
Palate:Medium light body, lightly creamy. 
Summary: A decent flavorful bock, kind of one note but enjoyable.

12 oz bottle- Pours very dark ruby red to black with a one finger tan head that reduces. Aroma is kind of sweet, chocolate, fairly subdued. The taste is chocolate malts, caramel, light hops impart a dryness in the finish. Good light and drinkable, well made.

dark brown pour with ruby highlights and a small but lasting tan head.
aroma is coffee, cocoa, roasted malt, light dried fruitiness.
flavour is nice roasted malt, cocoa, coffee, burnt bitterness but not astringent. Very well balanced. some hints of dried fruit again near the end. tasty.

Bottle: clear to light haze. Dark brown with tan head. Roasted, cocoa, coffee, dry fruit and toast. Malt driven and dark. Dry to off dry. Low bitterness to medium low. Maybe phenolic not bitter. Slight sour not that provides freshness not spoilage. Mocha, chocolate, coffee, malty and dates. Dense and long. Lovely texture. Probably the best beer Ive tasted from Full Sail to date. Balanced.

Dark brown with a tan head. The aroma has some strong chocolate and light roasted malt notes. The flavor has the same. I get some heavy chocolate and roasted malt notes. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Nice beer.

12 oz bottle from a six pack bought at Super 1 in Rathdrum, ID. Aroma is toasted marshmallow, chocolate, bread. Pours black with a one finger tan head that collapses fairly quick. Taste is sweet and roasty, slightly tart edges, wet river rock flavor. Very much like a porter. Creamy mouthfeel, medium body. Good beer.

7 Dec 2013, bottle. very dark ruby. nose is toasty malt, some christmas cake, bitter chocolate. med body, a bit creamy, slightly fizzy. chocolate malt and bitter chocolate finish. some spiced notes. very nice.
Faint charcoal nose. Mahogany, thick tan head, good retention. Charcoal and walnut flavor. Very subtle hints of dark chocolate.

Appearance: near black with a thick, rocky tan head and generous lacing.  Aroma: 	rich and roasty-dark, with chocolate, espresso, leather, pipe smoke, and a hint of licorice.  Taste: bittersweet and dry dark chocolate, with coffee, caramel, a hint of fire-smoke, slightly herbal, resinous hops.  Finish: 	surprisingly clean and dry, with a slightly chewy lingering roast character. Notes: Dunkler Bock? Schwarzbier? Who cares. This is astoundingly good. Huge aromas and flavors, and yet the palate, while rich, keeps things light enough to make this surprisingly refreshing. What a treat.
Chocolate, coffee, licorice, and raisin aroma and flavor. Medium bodied with a smooth lasting finish. I enjoy this beer every year!

almost black but clear, not bad on the head and lacing.

Aroma and flavor definitely do have notes of chocolate and coffee, especially chocolate. There are some toasty notes, and a little bit of dark fruits.

Body is pretty full for a lager, creamy and pretty smooth.

Interesting beer, certainly worth a try.

Pour on tap, dark reddish brown pour with thin white head, aroma brought dark roast, dark fruits, hints of toffee, slight biscuit in there as well with a touch of yeast, hints of cocoa in there, nice spicy notes as well. Taste is a mix of dark fruits, some roasted malts into a bit of coffee, cocoa, slight earth, spice, finishing with some more fruity notes, pretty sweet and dry.

Pours brown finger light tan head.

Smell coco and coffee roast.

Taste milk chocolate and a hint of lager yeast, good roasted malt.

Light bodied and easy drinking, no hint of booze.

Wonderful

12 ounce bottle from Beer Run. Pours a dark brown color with a thin fizzy tan head that fades almost instantly. Aroma of toffee, nuts, mild raisin and chocolate. The taste is chocolate, toffee, mild nuts. Thin-medium bodied, high carbonation. Solid beer .

12 oz bottle to shaker. Pour is dark and thick, dark copper color with a thick khaki color. Nose is strong malt, oat, dark chocolate, coffee, caramel. Taste is medium bodied, both bitter and sweet. Finishes very oily and smooth.

Pours clear reddish brown with a tiny bit of brown head. Aroma is caramel, earth, smoke. Taste is roasted malt, chocolate, tobacco, a hint of alcohol. Mouth feel is a bit thin given the big taste. Not my favorite style but I wouldnt turn down another one.
Rich, roasty aroma - nutty-sweet undertones. Pitchy pour, ivory head. Roasty, coffee, mildly sweet, parched soy, medium acidity. Roast finish, low bittering otherwise. On tap, Hay Merchant, Houston.

Bottle from Let's Pour. Roasty, chocolate aroma with notes of coffee and caramel. Pours black with very thin light brown head and no lacing. Roasted malt and caramel to start followed by chocolate and some coffee finishes smooth with the chocolate lingering on the palate.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Chocolate, allspice, nutmeg, med. roast coffee. Lactose, German earthy hops. Mild bitterness balanced with the creamy coffee body. This was much better than the fresh bottle !
Heaps of chocolate on the nose. A little malted, milky and with some vanilla in the mouth. Pretty thick. Deep and lightly sweet.

12oz bottle in a snifter. Pours dark brown with a beige head. Aroma of light roasted, chocolate, and coffee malts plus some dark fruits and light hops. Flavor the same. Average texture. A decent beer.

12oz served in a Sam Adams perfect pint glass.

A - Very dark brown with a khaki head that forms a thin collar. Average retention with zero lacing.

S - Caramel, cocoa, roasted malts, charred grass, black pepper, dairy sweetness.

T - Dark fruit bread, caramel, brown bread crust, toffee, molasses, cocoa, raspberries, cherries, old coffee, a woody bitterness on the back end. Finishes with some tangyness on he end.

M - Smooth creamy feel, low to medium carbonation, heavy side of medium bodied.

The chocolate stands out more than any other flavor to me, the flavor is breadier than the nose describes. I liked this one. The Euro Dark Lager style can be ho hum but this one shines through. Ive been impressed with all the ltd series.

Serving type: bottle

12-09-2012

Serving: from bottle.

Aroma: light apple aroma.

Appearance: very small, fizzy, light-brown, initial head with no lacing and fully diminishing longevity.  Dark-brown/black body.

Taste: moderately acidic and lightly chocolatey initial flavor and lightly sweet, roasted finish with hint of dates.  Long duration.

Palate: medium-to-full bodied with dry texture and lively carbonation.

Overall: interesting taste.

Bottle.  Deep, dark, reddish-brown.  There head is thin, but staying, and tan.  There is a bit of a chocolate aroma to this which is interesting.  Quite lush, and full of rich caramel malt, and a hint of milk, which answers the challenge on the label of "no chocolate or coffee."  Very well done.  (#4980, 4/12/2013)

Bottle. 4/11/13. Pours an opaque brown with a thin, bubbly off-brown head. Aroma is bread, earthy, chocolate, candi, fruit, lager. Taste is cereal, roast, coffee, dark chocolate, hints of dark fruit. Light lacing. Chewy, full mouth feel. I typically go for ales over lagers. This isnt bad. Full flavored. Nice body. Pretty good.

Thanks again to gregwilsonstl for sharing this one.  Pours dark brown with a reddish hue and a beige head.  The aroma has smooth roasted dark maltiness, cream, cocoa, nuttiness and lager smoothness.  Medium body with a mild amount of carbonation.  The flavor starts off with roasted nutty malt, cocoa, mild spice and a lushness to the malt.  The finish dries out a bit, but is still smooth and lush with nuttiness, roast and cocoa.  Nice.
Pour a dark brown with reddish hues and a light brown head. Aromas of dark fruit, smoke, malt, and caramel. Tastes mostly of caramel, fruit, toasted malt and nuts.

Deep brown with a short tan head.
Scent is chocolate, coffee....a little vanilla.
Taste is cola-like..malty.
Very pleasant.
Bottle from the Co-op in Davis, CA. Pours a dark brown with quite a bit of carbonation. Tastes of coffee with a hint of chocolate. Definite roasted malts with a hint of hop at the end. Solid brew.

Cola colored pour with a small khaki head. Sweet caramel, chocolate, and dark fruit aromas. A bit of roast, maybe some smoke, coffee, and licorice. A bit of cola, too. The flavor is quite sweet up front with a lot of caramel and dark fruit. Nice chocolate, roast, and coffee notes. A bit of smoke, some licorice, and a subtle hop flavor.
On tap. Dark brown with a thin off white top. Scent is caramel, fruit and chocolate. Taste is roasty, coffee and chocolate.

Bottle poured a dark cola color bordering on black with a coating of tan head. Aroma has dark roasted malt, chocolate, brown malt, and some earth. Mouth feel is light and the carbonation medium low. Flavor has a medley of darker malts, light bitterness, medium roast, earthy hops, and some chocolate.
Tap at Cincy Beerfest. Very light vanilla cola, and chocolate malt aroma. Deep mahogany with a small tan head. Light chocolate malt flavor. LIght to medium body, moderate carbonation.
Draft.  Light chocolate malt aroma.  Dark brown with small head.  Sweet chocolate/vanilla malt flavor.  Light but tasty.
This tastes like coffee, but they tell me there is none.  Surprised its this high alcohol.

Tap at the Stagshead this is quite yummy I dont mind saying.  pours black with nice head.  Nose of coffee and chocolate.  Tastes of chocolate, coffee, resin, earth, wood, and some dark fruits.  its creamy and smooth.

12oz bottle. Dark reddish brown with a fizzy light tan head. Aroma of chocolate, wheat bread, cola and a light mineral twang. Flavor of rich dark bread, chocolate, doughy yeast with a medium hop bitterness. Medium body with prickly carbonation. Nice beer, full flavor and very drinkable.

~Pleasant aroma of chocolate bread and coffee.
~Pours brownish black color with small lasting brownish white head.
~Chocolate bread flavor with light coffee. Really subtle roastiness.
~Medium light bodied with high CO2, chocolate lasting finish.
~This does remind me of some of the Dark beers I had in Prague.  Very nice.
Yummy, what a fun beer!  Very malty with the taste of coffee and chocolate, yet light and fuzzy.  Not very hoppy, but who cares?  Extra points for creativity!

Draught at Stags Head NYC. Pours black with reddish hues around the edges. Medium beige head.  Aroma is very slight, bits of caramel and dark fruit.   Tast is roasted malt with huints of chocolate. Really nice beer, finishes really very and very smoothly.

Pours deep dark reddish brown.  Aroma is dark chocolate, coffee, cinnamon and dark fruit.  Taste is sweet with some citrus bitter undertones.  Medium bodied, soft carbonation and slick texture.  Very enjoyable.

Chocolate, toast, roasty

Tastes amazing when served super chilled. Nice roasty taste with hints of chocolate and coffee.

This dark brown beer has strong coffee smells. It has a coffee flavor and a malty smoky richness. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Clear brown pour with dark chestnut highlights and ring of offwhite head.   Sweet plum nose like a dunkel. Tastes like caramel and figs/plums. Definitely roasty, and with some amount of coffee bitterness. Flavors are reminiscent of cocoa on the finish.  Its okay, it hits the flavor profile they claim, but its not amazing on any of that facets.  Meh.

Pretty good. I like the aroma of esspresso and hint of cocoa. Looks pitch black with wispy lil thin tan head. No legs. Taste is roasted coffee beans, caramel, dough, alco esters, earthy hops.  Palate is covered in dark full bodied creamy almost chewy mouthfeel. Overall this brew is real nice, its bold, flavorful, creamy toasty and yummy. Good brew.
Bottle into glass, pours clear black, with thin light brown head..coffe, and expresso taste,   some cream and chocolate..  good shit
Surprising coffee taste. Has a sweet musty smell. A dry, diluted stout flavor.

Thin tan head of small bubbles.  Light malts, chocolate, smoked grains and a bit of molasses.  Color is a very dark brown.  Lots of smokey flavors.  Beef jerkey, smoked and sweet malts, some peat and dark chocolate.  Lingering sweet and smokey malts.  An ok dunkler bock.

Bottle shared thanks to Dmac. Pours a nice pitch black with a small white head. Armoa is of chocolate, light roast, mild coffee, and some lingering sweetness. Taste is complex, silky smooth mouthfeel, with some nice chocolate notes, medium roast coffee, light grainy sweetness with a touch of bitterness. Solid.

Bottle: &nbsp Deep brown, thin frothy sandy head, little lacing. &nbsp Soft salty caramel nose, a little toasted and bready. &nbsp Bready on the tongue, slight dark pitted fruit, slightly nutty. &nbsp Backside has some cocoa or dark chocolate notes. &nbsp Little to no bitterness, malty all the way. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate. &nbsp A little acrid bitterness, or lets say super dark chocolate bitterness on the finish. &nbsp Decent.
Dark brown in color, clear with a thin head.  Nice flavors and aroma.  Loved the malt and hops mix this was a very nice beer.  Lots of chocolate and coffee like flavors.

Im a sucker for Full Sails LTD line - when I can get a bottle for $1 at Trader Joes.  They usually come up short, but that being said, this is one of the better Full Sail brews I have had.  Not much aroma, but decent.  Def. some chocolate taste in with the off/cheap malt and harsh lager flavors.  Those balance each other out a bit.  Over malted, but that may be right for style (first Dunkler, only five styles left).  Hurt by fake carbonation.

Wow, completely not what I was expecting.  Pours out a creamy black with a thin beige laceful head.  Sweet nose of caramel malts and dark malty sweetness, a little roast, with a hint of light cocoa and fig.  Flavor was woody and malty with heavy-medium sweetness, nice tones of chocolate and caramel mixed with a little raisin or other dark fruity tones, roastiness, and a long smooth creamy finish.  Nice little aftertaste of black licorice and dark earthy malty caramel.

12oz bottle shared with Headbanger poured into a Snifter at 48°.  Color is a deep near black brown with light carbonation and a thin tan head.  Aroma of chocolate and roasted malt.  Medium body with a smooth mouth feel.  Flavor of mild coffee, chocolate and some dried fruit.  In the after taste a faint bitterness caps it off.  Overall it a very tasty brew and is the best in the LTD series.

12oz bottle 1/16/13 (Crown Liquor Singles Cooler)-48° in Shaker-Pours black with a small tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, and chocolate. Taste of coffee, chocolate, roasted malt, and dried fruit om the back end. This medium bodied brew is well balanced and quite tasty. Probably the best of this series.
From 12 ounce bottle. Very smooth lager body with a pronounced caramel head. Tastes like a chocolate porter. Unique.
A Dunkler Bock or Black Lager. It really is unique, especially from an Oregon brewery. 7% alc. too!

Bottle-purchased january 2012-pours deep brown almost black with a small tan fizzy head.  much darker than i was expecting.  Nose is full of chocolate, lite dark fruits, lite caramel, roast/char.  pretty nice stuff!  flavors start with deep chocolate going onto some astringent roasted notes.  Some sweet chooclate helps balance the roasty notes.  this is pretty solid stuff!  Palate is lush, slick and full.  pretty well done!
Bottle. Dark mahogony beer with a dark tan head. Coffee and roast aroma. Chocolate and light roast flavor. medium bodied. Chocolate and caramel linger with light roast and light mineral notes.

6 pack purchased at Trader Joes in Davis, CA.  The aroma on this is quite roasted, with lightly sweet vanilla character and a little bit of chocolate, too.  Underlying anise and metallic character are also evident.  Mildly transparent dark mahogany body present with a medium light tan head.  Attractive brew. Wow, this tastes a little different than I expected.  Starts with a good deal of toastiness, before it becomes a little metallic with touches of anise in the middle.  Roasts follow, and then more dry, super toasty flavor comes through in the finish.  Unique, interesting flavor.  I like.

Sampled on 1/1/2013. This dunkeler pours a eclipse brown color from a 12oz bottle. Small to medium sized tan foamy head with good retention and nice lacing. The aroma is caramel, bready and sweet, with some chocolate and a hint of nuttiness. A medium bodied dunkel bock. The malts are caramel and sweet, with some chocolate. The hops are earthy and herbal. Nice carbonation. Semi sweet chocolate, some raisins and some dark fruit. Perhaps a touch on the sweet side, but kind of balanced by the chocolate. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.
Bottle.  Pours a brown color, with a light tan head.  Nice nuttiness, caramel malt, chocolate, and light roast.  A bit watery, but overall a tasty lager.

12oz bottle shared by Mike, thanks 
Appearance: Dark brown with a small tan, good lacing 
Aroma: Roasted malts and bakers chocolate 
Taste: Roasted malts, chocolate, bitter and bisquity 
Nice
Bottle from Total Wine, Sacramento. Pours dark brown with a huge tan head and a treacle aroma. There is a chocolate and coffee flavor that is a little bit  off, with a dry bitter finish.

Dark chocolate in color with a foamy tan head. Nose is bitter chocolate and coffee bean. Yummy mouthfeel is slight creamy but effervescent. Taste is chocolate malt , nuts, herb, and wood. A very appealing lager. Even as it warms, the alcohol in undetectable.

12oz bottle via 6pack from Spirits Middletown. Poured a good looking black center with super dark mahogany brown edges underneath an average sized creamy medium beige head. Aroma is like a chocolate egg creme, notes of light chocolate, lactose, wet nutts, medium toast and a tootsie roll wax wrapper. Medium bodied with softer carbonation and a creamy full finish. Flavor is much like the aroma where a light chocolate and lactose dominate followed by some dark fruit, wet nut shells and lightly burnt toast. I didnt like this out of the bottle, I hardly ever drink a beer that way, not sure if this needs to breath or if every beer is just beter from a glass. This one is without a doubt better poured into a wide mouth tulip for sure though.

I dispute the classification as a bock. This is much more of a dunkel,  albeit a strong one. Rich and heavy palate, very thick for a lager. Heavily roasted malt with flavors of coffee,  chocolate, and grain. Light hop aroma. Very good.

Almost a finger of tan head on a black colored body.
Smell is a strong roasted malt.
Taste has the roasted malt with coffee undertones. A flavorful lager.
Medium body with moderate carbonation. Crisper texture.
A tasty dark lager. The flavors of a stout in a lager.
Ruby black color with tan sheen. Dry burnt toast, vegetal aromas. medium body, average carbonation. Thin flavors of dark bread, dry chocolate, and mild vegetable--decent.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text:
Deep brown with tan head. Aroma of bready biscuity malt with toast, bakers chocolate and nutty notes. Flavor similar with some toasty Munich character and some light roast that dries out the finish. Clean lager character. Very nice. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 ounce bottle thanks to Mike. Pours a dark brown color with a medium beige head. A sweet nose of chocolates and toast. A sweet chocolate flavor, light toast, sweet light hops. Good. Very good actually.

Bottle. Pours amber brown with a beige head. Dark and wheaty malts, light chocolate, light dark fruits, and light earthy notes. This "LTD" series is pretty consistently good, and this is no exception.

Deep chestnut brown with fuzzy tan head.  Lots of chalky-sulfur lager aroma with a moderate amount of pure cocoa.  Medium-light body, fairly frothy, moderate coarseness, and moderate carbonation.  Flavor brings out fresh herbal grasses coupled with light chocolate and grains.  Not so much coffee, touch of dark burnt toast in there.  Light, fresh bitterness, with considerable linger time for the style.  Overall, more balanced towards hops and yeast complexity away from malt for the style.  Not bad, better than the aroma suggests, which isnt all that bad to begin with.
pine and citrus hop character lasts and seems a bit like ripe cherry. deep dark brew with bitter dark chocolate in the finish. dishwater soapy mellow in there.

Black but not opaque with a thin tan head and some lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, and coffee. Taste is similar to aroma but subdued and burnt, with a slightly bitter aftertaste. Lightly sweet, but not rich. Medium bodied and slick.
Bottle.Pours a rich, dark black with a nose of coppery cocoa and rusty malt.  Flavor is raspberry chocolate fudge with a hint of vanilla in the finish.  Watery mouthfeel.  Meh.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Light roasted aroma. Coffee-ish roasted malt flavor. Somewhat sweet; more so in the finish. Moderate bitterness. A little herbal/spicy flavor--assuming its hops.

12 oz. bottle served in shaker- poured a barely transparent when held to a light source black with heavy shading of darkened maroon, light carbonation, tan ring around the glass for a head that did lace extremely well.  Aroma of a caramel malt, molasses, milk chocolate, and FUCKING BEER!!!  Hits the mouth with a high-medium body, malt is extremely tasty with caramel laced within it, middle holds up fine, finish is sweetened light artificially but that does not stop from the enjoyment.  Beer.  Here.  Keep your bait n switch Texughtuckyass shit, and give me this.  Now.
Poured from a 12 ounce bottle. Very easy drinking, cannot tell this is 7%. Nice chocolate notes, floral, fruity hints, malty. This is one of the best in the LTD series that I have had.

pours a clear dark brown with a ruby tint, a small tan head, and some lacing.

smell is of some cocoa, roasted malt, and some prunes.

taste is somewhat watery, sweet malt, a slight amount of cocoa, a touch of coffee, and hops.  ends a little bitter.

bottle.  deep brown with a small beige head.  roasty, fruity aromas with nougat and tootsie rolls.  flavor blends caramel and chocolate(toostie rolls) with fruity figgy hop character.  kind of a big beer at 7% and leaves a warming finish that lets its presence be known.  medium full with a bit too much carbonation.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2012 Dark brown in the glass.  Nice coffee and dark cocoa aroma.  Flavor is similar to the aroma and the lager yeast gives it a nice crispness.  Overall, a tasty brew. Thanks to BarZigKin for sharing!

Appearance:  Pours dark brown, letting no light through.  Not much of a head, but a ring of tan froth around the edges and a few tan swirls looking down.

Aroma:  Roasted malt, slight wet dog, walnuts, chocolate.



Taste:  Roasted and toasty malt, spicy hops, a little sour twang in the middle. A touch of coffee. Finishes with long roast and hop spice.

Mouthfeel:  Full bodied with moderate carbonation.

Overall:  Pretty tasty, very bold, and a great edition to this craft lager series.

pours a very dark brown .. light head, dies down alot .. . chocolate, coffee, nuts and light bran .. . mild but assertive mouth .. . quite a nice bock, hides the abv very well! .. . . .. . . im a grown ass man!! - with a sunshine on your belly!?!

A dark black pour with a raspberry tint. The head is red stained tan and settles to a thin film. The aroma is misty cocoa malt. The flavor is ripe plum and roasty cocoa malt. Soft on the palate and finishes like cherry and.dark chocolate.
bottled, dark brown khaki colored pour with roasted chocolate aroma, flavor is well balanced chocolate , some roasted pecans, cinnamon, good balance and finish

Interesting and pleasant. Nice aroma of malt, coffee and a little chocolate. Nice chocolate color with a small head that was gone in a flash. Smooth palate that was a little creamy. The initial taste was of coffee and chocolate malts, not artificial. Later in the beer a bitter and burnt essence came out that was somewhat like licorice. Good but there are ones better.

On tap at the Full Sail Pilsener Room in Portland, OR. Pours a deep brown, mostly black colored body with a finger-width, dense and creamy, light brown head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma has some chocolate, grainy nuts, touches of dark fruit, a light roast and toast, and a light caramel. Flavor is similar. Nutty, somewhat grainy, lightly sweetened chocolate and caramel up front before some toast, touches of earth, and a few dark fruits come in. Roasts come out more towards the end as this finishes clean, malty, and dry with a very light bitterness before leaving a lengthy aftertaste. Medium-full, rounded and soft body with a creamy, moderate carbonation. Overall, a pretty tasty beer. Nice chocolate and roast notes in a smooth, creamy, easy drinking body. Not bad.

Location: 12 oz bottle from Oak Tree, 11/29/12


Aroma: The nose has some roasted malts, coffee, and a little caramel

Appearance: This one pours a dark brown color with a small head and minimal lace

Flavor: The taste is also pretty roasty, with a light sweetness, and a light bitterness

Palate: This one has a medium body, decent drinkability, and a fairly short, lightly dry finish

Overall Impression: 
This one is fine, but not much more then that.  Nothing really, truly stood out as exceptional here, theres so roasted coffee and some other decent components.  Solid overall, but a little forgettable.  It has a decent feel to it as well.
Bottle. Trader Joes.  Dark pour. Tan head. Aroma of cocoa and dark coffee. Flavor is dark roasted malt with a distinctive slightly sweet flavor.

Picked up a sixer of this for $5, score! The label mentions chocolate but I would not go that far. Dark black color, decent head. Smells roasty, dark, malts. Flavor is more of the same, very dark malts. This is a good lager, not sure what style it would be because Im pretty much a novice at drinking lager beers. I would definitely buy another one of these for $5, that was a fucking steal.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-27-2012 21:05:05

Bottle @ home, picked up at Wilburs Fort Collins. Pours a dark brown head with a brown head. Rich cocoa, anise, light caramel, a touch nutty, herbal aroma. Kind of chewy, chocolate covered raisin, grassy, caramel, dark fruity, light toffee flavor. Not bad.
Pours dark brown with a small tan head.  Rich sweet aroma.  Chocolate malt taste with some lingering bitterness.  Medium smooth mouthfeel.  Gets better as it warms.  Filling finish.
Poured a medium to heavy dark brown. medium khaki head. Lots of notes of chocolate and dark malt.
Bottle. Very dark pour with minimal head. Very nice aroma and taste of sweet chocolate, dark fruit, and mild roast. Decent heft to the palate. Im enjoying this.

Bottle from Total Wine in Sacramento, CA. Pours very dark brown with ruddy glints. De minimis tan head. Aromas of roast malt, chocolate and dark fruit. Full bodied. Flavor is roast malt, coffee, chocolate, and something raisin. Its pushing towards dry,but cant quite get there. It seems to have noble hop in the bitter. Quite tasty.

12 oz single from "Lifesource" in Salem.
$1.49
Pours a gorgeous dark brown with a huge rocky,yet thick and lasting tan head.
Aroma is mostly dark chocolate ,hazelnuts and cream fudge. A little alcohol shows at first sniff then is gone.
Creamy,toffee,chocolate taste..very smooth   then a slight bitter ater tatse, very nice.
Good on the palate..the beer gives the impression of heaviness but it fairly flows over the tongue.
Overall an excellent beer best of the LTD series.
Bottle from Trader Joes. Deep ruby on the pour. Roasty nose with a little sweet chocolate. Smooth and full bodied. Good roast with an almost burnt finish. Some bitterness as well.
Bottle.  Youre so forgettable.  Completely forgettable.  When I think back to this beer I had two days ago, my brain thinks of nothing cuz you are so....forgettable.  And watery, and meh.

Now this is a great burger beer. Full Sail knows how to do light and sessionable. This black hued beer has a thin head and loads of chocolate notes. Mostly light and milky. But the beer doesnt taste thin and watery.

Bottle.

Head is initially small, frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is dark brown.

Aroma is moderately malty (cocoa powder, roasted grain), lightly hoppy (flowers).

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly to moderately bitter.

Medium body, watery/syrupy texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic.

Sigh.  What a simple, uninviting aroma!  Clunky cocoa powder is really about it, minor roast.  Syrupy sweet in the mouth without much to balance.  Black bock?  Uh, sure, whatever.

bottle.  cola brown with a small head, less than average retention.  stewed caramel malt, solvent phenols and fusel alcohols in the nose with a sweet caramel syrup malt smell and touches of beach sand, sulfur and minerals.  pasty and rough malt with distinct burnt grain harshness and a malt liquor petroleum / ethanol flavor.  acidic and chalky and pasty and sourish cola-flavor malts all over it.  pretty bad.

Draft at the brewery. Pours a deep, somewhat cloudy mahogany with almost no head. Aroma of chocolate and roasted malts, nuts, molasses, and dates. Flavor follows suit. Nice balance. Medium body with modest carbonation and a malty mouthfeel. Really nice. Hit the spot.
Pours dark brown with little head. Big coffee aroma and taste with some chocolate and figs. Thank you sir, may I have another?
Bottle.  Very dark with a beige head.  Fruity aroma.  Roast malt flavour with a light caramel note.  Well balanced finish
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: Smells roasty and toasty. Tastes kinda like an American brown ale or a stronger black lager, very roasty, but balanced and dry.

A near perfect beer.  Smells of oats and alcohol.  Delivers on coffee, alcohol, chocolate flavors. I think it tastes as though there is some whisky/oak flavors also in the mix.  Mouthfeel is baffling light until you look at the bottle and are reminded it is a lager. It also is a steal at seven bucks a six pack.  I would pay that much for a bomber of this.
Out of the bottle. Pours a very dark brown color with a fine tan head. Subtle and pleasant roasted smell. Very strong roasted flavor with a very clean finish. This is an excellent beer!

Pours a deep, dark ruby - fizzy, but fails to kick up a head - kind of looks like dark black cherry soda - a bit of chocolate and caramelized sugars in the nose first - a moderate melanoidin quality - however, there is also a bit of alcohol and grain husk as well - slick in the mouth - moderate carbonation - flavor is medium sweet but also lightly tart - moderate chocolate, hazelnut - thankfully, none of the huskiness from the nose is present, but neither is the rich melanoidin note - finish or warming alcohol and caramel - a little spice - its decent, but a bit rough - I much prefer their lower abv LTD lagers.

Bottle at Columbia Distributions Winter Ales Tasting in Eugene. Really, really nice. An even, brown color and a nice coffee-tinged taste. If it werent for the ABV, this would be eminiently sessionable. A great choice if youre after a true lager in the winter.
Bottle...  Poured deep, dark brown with a mild forming head.  Notes of roasted malts, dark sugars. cocoa, coffee, and nuts & grains.  Solid LTD offering from Full Sail.

Bottle. Pours a  very dark brown with minimal head. Like the description says, there is a lot of roasting and some hints of chocolate to the nose, and the coffee really comes through in the taste. Great drink.
